contents.title: Documentation
contents.description: Welcome to the documentation for Yabal.

children.value: Welcome to the documentation for Yabal.
If you have any questions about Yabal or Astro-8, feel free to ask them in the

contents.title: Downloads
contents.description: Download the Yabal compiler and Astro-8 emulator.

children.value: On this page you can download the Yabal compiler and the Astro-8 emulator.
Yabal contains the compiler and emulator.
Astro-8 emulator an emulator for Astro-8. In comparison to the Yabal emulator it supports more features like audio and file I/O.

contents.title: Emulator
contents.description: Learn how to run your Yabal programs.

children.value: To run your Yabal programs, you need to install the Astro-8 emulator. The Astro-8 emulator is a virtual machine that runs Astro-8 assembly code. Yabal compiles your code to Astro-8 assembly code, which is then run by the emulator.
It is recommended to install the
to run your programs, since the emulator contains all the latest features like audio and file system support.
To start your script with the native Astro-8 emulator, add the

props.code: yabal run program.yabal -n

children.value: If you want to pass arguments to the native emulator, add
and move the file name to the end of the command. After that, you can pass arguments to the emulator:

props.code: yabal run -n -- program.yabal -f 1000

children.value: For all the options of the native emulator,
If you don't want to install the Astro-8 emulator, you can use the built-in emulator instead. However, the built-in emulator is not as feature-rich as the native emulator.
To start your program with the built-in emulator, run the following command:

props.code: yabal run program.yabal

contents.title: Basics of Yabal
contents.description: Learn about the basics of Yabal.

children.value: This page will teach you the basics of Yabal.
Comments are used to add notes to your code. They are ignored by the compiler.
There are two types of comments in Yabal: single-line comments and multi-line comments.
and end at the end of the line:

props.code: // This is a single-line comment

children.value: Yabal is a statically typed language. An statically typed language means that the type of a variable is known at compile time. This is in contrast to a dynamically typed language (like JavaScript), where the type of a variable is only known at runtime.
of values of the specified type
A struct is a user-defined type. It contains a number of fields, which can be of any
keyword, followed by the name of the struct, and then a block of code surrounded by curly braces (

).
Within the block of code, you can declare fields by specifying the
For example, we declare a struct called
An array is a collection of values of the same type. Arrays are declared using the

props.code: int[] numbers // An array of integers

children.value: The actual code in a Yabal program is made up of statements. Common statements are variable declarations, declaring functions, calling functions and control flow statements.
A statement can be a single line of code that ends with a new-line or
. A statement can also be multiple lines of code surrounded by curly braces (
The following code shows an example of a block of code:
// If statement that contains multiple statements
An expression is a statement that evaluates to a value. For example,
is an expression that evaluates to
Expressions can be used in many places, such as in assignment statements, function calls, and control flow statements.
Variables are used to store values in memory.
You can declare variable specifying the

props.code:
// Create an integer variable called "variable"
int variable

children.value: You can also assign a value to a variable when declaring it by using the

props.code:
// Create an integer variable called "variable" and assign it the value 1
int variable = 1

children.value: // Create an integer variable called "variable" and assign it the value 1
It is also possible to let the compiler infer the type of the variable. This is done by using the

keyword.
The compiler will look at the value that is assigned to the variable, and infer the type from that:

props.code:
// Create an integer variable called "variable" and assign it the value 1
var variable = 1

children.value: // Create an integer variable called "variable" and assign it the value 1
Semi-colons can be used to separate statements. They are optional, but are required if you want to put multiple statements on the same line.

props.code: int a = 1

children.value: But this is not, since there are multiple statements on the same line:

props.code: int a = 1 int b = 2

children.value: If you want to put multiple statements on the same line, you can use semi-colons to separate them:

props.code: int a = 1; int b = 2

children.value: Functions are used to reuse code. When you declare a function with code, you can call it from other places in your code.
and name of the function, followed by the parameters of the function in parentheses (
), and then a block of code surrounded by curly braces (
To return a value from a function, use the
keyword followed by the value to return.
For example, the following code declares a function called
that takes two integers as parameters and returns an integer:
// The function takes two integers (a and b) as parameters and returns an integer
Functions can also be declared without a return type by specifying
as the return type. A function with a return type of
For example, the following code declares a function called
that takes a int array as a parameter and returns nothing:
// Print the value to the screen
To call a function, use the name of the function followed by the arguments of the function in parentheses (
For example, the following code calls the

props.code:
// Call the add function and store the result in the "result" variable
int result = add(1, 2)

children.value: // Call the add function and store the result in the "result" variable

html.dark .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-dark);background: var(--shiki-dark-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-dark-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-dark-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-dark-text-decoration);}html .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-default);background: var(--shiki-default-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-default-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-default-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-default-text-decoration);}html .default .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-default);background: var(--shiki-default-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-default-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-default-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-default-text-decoration);}html .dark .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-dark);background: var(--shiki-dark-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-dark-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-dark-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-dark-text-decoration);}
Yabal is a programming language for

, a custom 16-bit homebrew CPU. Yabal stands for "Yet Another Basic Astro-8 Language".
It is a simple language that is easy to learn and use, and compiles to Astro-8 assembly.
A struct is a data structure that can contain multiple fields. A struct can be used to group related data together. For example, the following struct can be used to represent a 2D point:

It is also possible to declare a field with a bit-width. This is useful if you want to read data from a hardware device, such as a mouse. For example, the following struct can be used to read the position of a mouse, and the state of its left and right buttons:

When declaring a field with a bit-width, the compiler will automatically add bit-wise operations to get and set the value of the field. This means that the field will be slower to access than a normal field.
It is not recommended to use bit-fields unless you are reading data from a hardware device.
Bit-fields are aligned by 16 bits. It is not possible to start a bit-field outside the 16 bit range. For example:
// Note: the following example will not compile
// This is valid, offset 0 with 7 bits
// This is valid, offset 7 with 7 bits
// This is invalid, offset 14 with 7 bits: 14 + 7 > 16
When a normal field is introduced, the bit-field offset is reset to the 16 bit boundary. For example:

contents.title: Language reference
contents.description: All the details about the language.

children.value: This section contains all the details about the Yabal language.

contents.title: Assembly mode
contents.description: Learn how to write raw assembly code in Yabal.

children.value: Yabal has a special mode called "assembly mode". In assembly mode, you can write assembly code directly in your program.
To enter assembly mode, use the
keyword, followed by a block of code surrounded by curly braces (
Assembly mode is useful if you want to use an instruction that is not supported by Yabal, or if you want to optimize a piece of code.
The default comment style in assembly mode is the same as in Yabal (
for multi-line comments) but you can also use assembly comments.
and end at the end of the line:
These comments are are included in the generated assembly code, which can be useful for adding notes to the assembly code.
To see the list of supported assembly instructions, see the
In addition to the instructions listed in the instruction set documentation, Yabal also supports the following instructions:
Jump to the specified label if register
Jump to the specified label if register
Jump to the specified label if register
Jump to the specified label if register
is less than or equal to register
Jump to the specified label if register
Jump to the specified label if register
is greater than or equal to register
Labels are used to mark a location in the assembly code. They are used by jump instructions to jump to a specific location in the code.
Labels are declared by writing the name of the label, followed by a colon (
To jump to a label, use the
It is only possible to jump to labels that are declared in the same assembly block.
In assembly mode, you can get the address of a variable by using
followed by the name of the variable:

props.code:
int a = 1

asm {
    AIN @a // Read the value of a into register A
    LDIB 1 // Load the value 1 into register B
    ADD // Add the value of register B to register A
    STA @a // Store the value of register A into a
}

children.value: // Read the value of a into register A
// Load the value 1 into register B
// Add the value of register B to register A
// Store the value of register A into a

contents.title: Optimizing
contents.description: Learn how to optimize your program.

children.value: This section contains tips and tricks for optimizing your program.
Before the compiler compiles the code to assembly, it will try to replace all constant values with their actual value.
For example, let's say we have the following code:

props.code: var a = 1 + 2

children.value: Without optimizing, the compiler will generate the following assembly code:

props.code:
LDIA 1
LDIB 2
ADD

children.value: With optimizing, the compiler will replace the constant values with their actual value, and the generated assembly code will be:

props.code: LDIA 3

children.value: When you declare a function with
, the compiler will replace all calls to the function with the function body.
, this can drastically reduce the size of your program.
For example, let's create a program that sets the first pixel on the screen to red:
This will produce the following assembly code. Note, this is without the function body:

props.code:
, Call the function
LDW
HERE 132 , Label L6
SWPC
LDW
HERE 140 , Label L5
STA 24
BIN 24
JMP
HERE 25 , Yabal:call

, Label L6: Prepare arguments
LDIA 255
STA 7 , [Stack:0]
LDIA 0
STA 8 , [Stack:1]
LDIA 0
STA 9 , [Stack:2]
JMP
HERE 91

, Label L5: Return, load the return value and update the screen
AIN 12 , Yabal:return_value
SWP
LDW
HERE 53871
BNK 1
STAOUT
BNK 0

children.value: , Label L5: Return, load the return value and update the screen
If we change the function to
, the compiler will replace all calls to the function with the function body:
Because the parameter values are constant, the compiler can calculate the result at compile time, and replace the inline function call with the result.
This will produce the following assembly code:

props.code:
LDIA 992
SWP
LDW
HERE 53872
BNK 1
STAOUT
BNK 0
